Breaking

Gerald Broth Announces Hostile Takeover of Panera’s Loyalty Program: “Their Points Mean Nothing. Ours Mean Soup.”

By Margaret Stockton • Feb 10, 2026 • 4 min read

In a move that surprised absolutely no one who has met him, Broth Exchange founder and CEO Gerald Broth (legal name, he will show you the birth certificate, he has shown seven reporters the birth certificate) announced plans to acquire and dissolve Panera Bread's rewards system.

“Every Panera point is a broken promise,” Broth said from behind a desk made entirely of solidified ramen broth. “They give you points. Points! A dimensionless abstraction. I give you soup. You can hold soup. You can taste soup. You can feel soup cooling against your palm as you contemplate the person you’re about to go on a date with.”

The proposed acquisition would convert all 41 million Panera Sip Club members into Broth Exchange accounts at a rate of 1,000 points = 0.3 bowls of store-brand chicken noodle. Broth called this “generous, considering.”

Panera has not responded. Their legal team reportedly received the offer letter in a thermos.

“I was on Wall Street for 14 years. I watched numbers go up. I watched numbers go down. One day in February 2019, during the polar vortex, a stranger handed me a cup of soup, and I understood for the first time that value is warm.” — Gerald Broth, founder’s letter, The Broth Exchange IPO prospectus (Initial Public Offering of 10,000 bowls)
Romance

Local Couple Credits Broth Exchange for Marriage: “He Solved the Riddle in 11 Seconds. I Knew.”

By Diane Noodle • Feb 9, 2026

When Theresa Mangiafuoco, 34, watched her now-husband Kevin solve the Entry Riddle in 11 seconds flat during a live Broth Exchange onboarding session, she experienced what Gerald Broth calls “the Ladle Moment”—the instant you recognize someone’s worth through soup-adjacent problem-solving.

“Most people take 2–3 minutes,” Theresa said. “Some people never get it. Kevin just looked at it, said ‘a towel,’ and I thought: this man will never let the soup get cold.”

They were married in the Broth Exchange’s Mezzanine Dining Room. The ceremony cost 40 bowls of wedding soup (naturally). Kevin’s vows included a riddle. Theresa solved it in 8 seconds.

Finance

Favor Futures Surge After Regional Manager Promises to “Help Everyone Move This Weekend”

By Richard Bouillon • Feb 10, 2026

The Favor Index (FAVOR.IDX) rose 47 favors in early trading after Southwest Regional Manager Denise Krupnik publicly committed to helping “literally anyone in the greater Tampa area move apartments this weekend, no questions asked.”

Analysts warn this is unsustainable. “She has one truck,” noted chief economist Paul Bisque. “She has a Honda CR-V. This is 2008 all over again. The favor bubble is real and it’s inflating in Tampa.”

Krupnik was unavailable for comment. She was helping someone move.

OPINION: Stop Calling It a “Soup Cult”

Gerald Broth, Founder & Chief Broth Officer

Every week I receive letters (many of which are printed below, against my wishes) from people calling The Broth Exchange a “soup cult.” Let me be clear: cults don’t have a NASDAQ-adjacent ticker. Cults don’t file taxes in soup. Cults don’t have a dating app with a 93% riddle pass rate and a 74% second-date rate.

We are a federally unrecognized financial institution that happens to also facilitate romance, and our currency happens to be soup. If that makes us a cult, then JPMorgan Chase is a cult that worships rectangles of cotton-linen blend.

I rest my case. Please stop sending me pamphlets about deprogramming. My mother has sent four.

Riddles

This Week’s Entry Riddle Stumps 7% of Applicants; Gerald Calls It “The Easiest One Yet”

By Susan Brodo • Feb 8, 2026

The current Entry Riddle, which all new members must solve before accessing any Broth Exchange services, has a 93% pass rate—the highest since the institution’s founding. Gerald Broth expressed disappointment.

“I wanted to filter for intelligence AND emotional depth,” he said. “But the board—” (Gerald is the board) “—insisted we make it accessible. Next quarter I’m introducing a second riddle. And a soup tasting.”

Analysis

Q4 Soup Earnings: Ramen Posts Record Gains While Gazpacho Enters Third Consecutive Seasonal Depression

By Paul Bisque, Chief Soup Economist • Feb 10, 2026

The Broth Exchange's Q4 numbers are in, and the picture is clear: hot soups dominate winter, and everyone who invested heavily in gazpacho futures is, once again, weeping into their cold tomato water.

Ramen (RAMEN.TKY) closed the quarter at an all-time high of 89.4 bowls per unit, driven by what analysts call "the infinite scarf effect"—when it's cold, people want ramen, and when they have ramen, they want to stay in, and when they stay in, they want to use the dating app, which requires more soup to pay for the subscription.

Pho (PHO.VNM) also posted strong numbers at 72.1 bowls, though concerns linger about a speculative bubble among users who "don't actually like pho but invested because the ticker symbol is fun to say."

Meanwhile, Gazpacho (GAZPACHO) continued its winter slide to 14.2 bowls—its lowest valuation since Gerald Broth publicly called it "a salad that gave up" in a 2023 press conference. Gazpacho traders have formed a support group. They meet on Tuesdays. Attendance is cold.

French Onion (FRENCH.ON) surprised analysts by holding steady at 52.1 bowls despite a cheese shortage in the midwest that threatened to undermine its core value proposition. "Without the cheese, it's just sad onion water," noted Broth Exchange floor trader Helen Consommé. "But people held. They believed in the cheese. The cheese came back."

“Diversify your broth portfolio. I cannot stress this enough. If you are 100% in chicken noodle, you are one poultry shortage away from romantic and financial ruin.” — The Broth Exchange Official Investment Guide, p. 14
Commodity Alert

Clam Chowder Experiences Flash Crash After Influencer Claims “Chowder Is Just Milk Soup”

By Tom Velouté • Feb 9, 2026

Clam Chowder (CLAM.CHWD) lost 4.7 bowls in 90 minutes of trading after lifestyle influencer @BrothOrNothing posted a video captioned "chowder is just milk soup and you can't date someone whose currency is milk soup." The post received 2.3 million views before Gerald Broth issued an emergency response video from what appeared to be a bathtub full of New England clam chowder.

"Chowder is NOT milk soup," Broth said, visibly emotional and covered in potatoes. "Chowder is a COMMITMENT. It's HEAVY. It STAYS WITH YOU. Which is more than I can say for most of the relationships on Hinge."

Markets stabilized by close of trading. Gerald remained in the bathtub for an additional two hours "as a show of solidarity."

Regulation

SEC Sends Fifth Letter Asking Gerald Broth to “Please Explain What This Is”

By Margaret Stockton • Feb 7, 2026

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has sent its fifth formal inquiry to The Broth Exchange, this time with the subject line "Genuinely, What Is This." Previous letters were titled "Inquiry Regarding Unlicensed Securities Activity," "Follow-Up: Is This a Joke," "Third Request: Seriously," and "We Are Sending Someone."

Gerald Broth responded to each letter with a thermos of soup and a handwritten riddle. The SEC reportedly solved three of the five riddles, which technically qualifies them for a Basic Broth Account.

"We welcome regulatory oversight," Broth said. "We also welcome the SEC to our Valentine's Day mixer. It's 12 bowls per person. There will be a riddle."

Feature

How The Broth Exchange Dating Algorithm Actually Works (It’s Soup Compatibility)

By Diane Noodle • Feb 10, 2026 • 6 min read

Many new members are surprised to learn that The Broth Exchange dating algorithm does not use any of the metrics common to other dating platforms. There are no personality quizzes. No swiping. No photos (Gerald considers them "a crutch for the unriddled mind"). Instead, the algorithm matches users based entirely on their Soup Portfolio.

"If two people both hold significant positions in French Onion, they share a fundamental worldview," explained Head of Romance Engineering Dr. Brenda Goulash. "They believe in patience. In layers. In the transformative power of heat applied to alliums over time. These people will understand each other."

Conversely, a heavy Gazpacho investor matched with a Ramen maximalist has a statistically 0% chance of lasting past the first date. "One of them wants something cold and refreshing. The other wants something that takes 12 hours to prepare. These people will fight about the thermostat. It's thermodynamic incompatibility."

The system also factors in Riddle Time (how quickly you solved the Entry Riddle), Favor Balance (how many outstanding favors you owe or are owed), and something called the "Ladle Quotient," which Gerald refuses to explain beyond saying "you know it when you feel it."

Controversial new feature: users can now pay 3 extra bowls to see their match's soup portfolio before the first date. Critics call this "broth-stalking." Gerald calls it "due diligence."

🔒 Solve the Entry Riddle to Unlock Premium Romance Content

"I dry as I get wetter. What am I?"

Unlocked

The 5 Love Languages, Translated to Soup

By Dr. Brenda Goulash, Head of Romance Engineering

Words of Affirmation: Telling your partner their minestrone is "structurally sound."

Acts of Service: Stirring. Just stirring. For hours. Without being asked.

Receiving Gifts: Surprise bowls. Left on the doorstep. Still warm. No note. They know.

Quality Time: Eating soup in silence across from each other. The soup speaks.

Physical Touch: Gerald has declined to comment on this one. He turned red and said "the soup is the touch." We did not follow up.

Success Story

“We Both Invested Everything in Miso. Now We Live in Kyoto.”

By Diane Noodle • Feb 6, 2026

Andrea Chen, 29, and Marcus Webb, 31, were matched by The Broth Exchange in March 2024 after the algorithm identified a 97.3% Soup Portfolio overlap. Both held aggressive positions in miso (MISO.JPN), both solved the Entry Riddle in under 20 seconds, and both listed their favorite favor as "airport pickup, no questions asked."

They went on their first date at a ramen shop in Chicago. They now live in Kyoto, where they operate a small miso production facility that supplies The Broth Exchange's Pacific Rim desk. Their wedding registry was 100% soup bowls. Gerald cried. He says he didn't. There is video.

Classifieds & Notices

Rates: 0.5 bowls per line • Minimum 2 lines • Riddles accepted as partial payment

Letters to the Editor

From: Craig Milford, Scottsdale, AZ

Dear Editor, I have been a loyal member of The Broth Exchange for two years. I have paid my subscription in soup every month. I have solved every riddle. I have gone on fourteen dates. I have not found love. My pantry is empty. I am surrounded by IOUs for favors I have called in. I am beginning to think this is just a very elaborate soup kitchen with a riddle problem. Please advise.

Editor's Response: Craig, your Soup Portfolio shows you are 100% invested in consommé. Consommé is a clarified broth. It is transparent. It hides nothing. This is beautiful, but it is also terrifying to most people. Consider diversifying into something opaque. We recommend chowder. —G.B.
From: Janet Broth (no relation), Portland, OR

I am TIRED of people assuming I'm related to Gerald. My last name is Broth. His last name is Broth. That is where the similarities end. I am a CPA. I do not trade in soup. I do not believe in riddles as a filtering mechanism for romantic compatibility. I have never once held a position in Gazpacho. PLEASE stop forwarding me his press releases. I get enough soup in the mail already.

Editor's Response: Janet, we have investigated and can confirm you are not related to Gerald. However, your surname does qualify you for a 15% discount on Premium Broth Accounts. This is non-negotiable. It's in the bylaws. —G.B.
From: The SEC, Washington, D.C.

Mr. Broth, this is not a "letter to the editor." This is a formal regulatory communication. Please stop publishing our correspondence in your newspaper. Please stop sending us soup. Agent Morrison is lactose intolerant and the chowder was not appreciated.

Editor's Response: We apologize to Agent Morrison. A lactose-free miso has been dispatched. Your Entry Riddle timer starts now. —G.B.
From: Gerald's Mother, Deborah Broth, Boca Raton, FL

Gerald, please call me. I don't understand what you're doing. Your father and I met at a normal bar. We used money. Are you eating enough? Not soup. Real food. Please call.

Editor's Response: Mom, I've asked you to use the proper channels. Your letter has been docked 0.5 bowls for not including a riddle. I am eating fine. Soup IS real food. —G.

Corrections & Clarifications

  • Feb 8: An earlier version of this article stated that Gazpacho was "dead." Gazpacho is not dead. It is seasonal. We regret the existential distress this caused Gazpacho traders.
  • Feb 6: We incorrectly reported that Gerald Broth was "seen eating a sandwich." Gerald has confirmed he was holding the sandwich for a friend and did not consume any non-soup food items. The Broth Exchange does not endorse sandwiches.
  • Feb 4: The Entry Riddle printed in last Tuesday's edition contained a typo that made it unsolvable. 412 applicants were denied entry. They have been credited 2 bowls each and offered a formal apology in the form of a new, solvable riddle.
  • Feb 1: We stated that "soup is the only valid currency." We have been advised by our legal team to clarify that the U.S. dollar is also technically a valid currency, though we maintain it is spiritually inferior.
  • Jan 29: The photo accompanying "Couple Marries at Broth Exchange Headquarters" was actually a photo of Gerald Broth crying alone in the Mezzanine Dining Room. We regret the error. Gerald does not regret the crying.
